nodes.text: Machine learning (ML) can provide novel insights and solve important challenges in reliability engineering and safety, improving analysis of accident, degradation, and survival data and enabling better decision-making and accident prevention
ML categories relevant to reliability and safety include supervised, unsupervised, semi-supervised, and reinforcement learning, each with distinct tasks and applicable algorithms

Supervised ML (regression and classification) has been successfully applied to remaining useful life (RUL) estimation, degradation prediction, and fault detection across domains (batteries, bearings, engines, turbines)

Unsupervised ML (clustering and anomaly detection) is useful for discovering patterns, operational modes, and early fault detection from unlabeled or streaming sensor data in industrial, structural, and spacecraft systems

Semi-supervised and reinforcement learning address problems with limited labels and sequential decision-making respectively, enabling improved prognostics, fleet-level maintenance policies, and inspection scheduling
ML model choice depends on task and data; no single model is universally best (No Free Lunch), so benchmarking and selection are essential in reliability and safety studies

Specific supervised methods used include SVR, GPR, decision trees, random forests, and deep neural networks; GPR gives principled uncertainty quantification, deep models handle high-dimensional nonlinear data

Anomaly detection techniques (OC-SVM, CNN, LSTM, autoencoders, Normal Behavior Models) can detect point and contextual anomalies but face challenges with false alarm rates and scalability, especially for spacecraft telemetry
Reinforcement learning and Deep RL can address large state-action problems in condition-based maintenance and inspection scheduling where MDP/POMDP scale poorly
Semi-supervised graph-based methods, ladder networks, and variational/deep generative models can leverage abundant unlabeled data to improve RUL and fault classification when labels are scarce
Authors should include transparent comparative model analysis and selection when applying ML in reliability and safety to justify chosen approaches

Future opportunities include (1) uncertainty quantification and deployment considerations, (2) fleet-level and system-of-systems PHM, (3) integrating ML with accident databases and safety management systems, (4) ML with wearable sensors for predictive safety, and (5) use of advanced models (Deep Gaussian Processes, GANs)

Evidence from spacecraft and industrial applications shows deep models (LSTM, CNN, autoencoders) can flag contextual anomalies and extract features from raw telemetry but currently suffer high false positive rates limiting operational adoption
Safe Reinforcement Learning (SRL) is required when online learning could explore unsafe states; SRL incorporates safety constraints, risk metrics, or external knowledge to limit hazardous exploration

Limitation: ML adoption is hindered by fragmented literature, high computational cost of deep models, interpretability concerns, publication bias favoring positive SSL results, and operational issues like false alarms

Conclusion: Integrating ML into reliability and safety toolkits can materially improve prognostics, anomaly detection, and decision-making but requires attention to uncertainty quantification, model selection, deployment, and ML system safety
